Our school year has started with students learning in-person and at home, and we are so grateful for the patience, understanding, resilience, and perseverance demonstrated by all as we adjust to the changes in our teaching and learning environments.

We want to continue to improve and provide quality learning experiences for all students in Belton. We have learned a great deal in these first 13 instructional days. Listening to our students, parents, and teachers to understand what is working well and what can be improved upon, the decision was made to add two additional staff professional development days to the 2020-2021 calendar:

Monday, September 21, 2020

Monday, November 9, 2020

There will be no in-person or virtual classes on these days. A new copy of the 1-page calendar is available on our website: https://bit.ly/BSDCalendars

School-age childcare (SAC) and Preschool-age childcare (PAC) will be available to families who currently use these services. More details about SAC and PAC will be shared as the first date nears.

Some of the plays developed from the Roundtable will receive a production or a staged reading on The Coterie's mainstage in the spring, if possible. Professional directors will assist the playwrights as their work is taken from the page to the stage. These works will be presented in the spring of 2021.

Rushing was nominated to the Roundtable after participating in The Coterie‚Äôs Reaching the Write Minds playwriting workshop through the 2020 Fringe Festival.

We are happy to share the news that the USDA has extended the Summer Feeding Program for all children up to 18 years of age. This means all students in the Belton School District can receive meals at no cost. At this time, the extension goes through December 18, 2020 - our last day before Winter break. These changes go into effect on Tuesday, September 8, 2020.

How this will impact your child:

ePirates (learning from home) can order their meals the night before and pick up between 9 - 10 am at Yeokum Center of Innovation, 613 Mill Street. Orders need to be placed by 7 pm the night before by simply filling out this form. The menu for ePirates can be found on our website. Students will receive meals at no cost.

In-person (learning at school) can receive meals at no cost. Menus have been updated for our in-person learners. Those can be found on our website and/or our app.

Check out some of the YUM from this week in the photos!
#Proud2BPirates

The 2020-2021 7th and 8th graders in the Community, Service, and Leadership classes prepared and assembled 1000 face shields that were donated to the Belton School District from Milbank Manufacturing, a proud American manufacturer for over 90 years in the Kansas City area. The face shields (in addition to masks) will be used by staff in a variety of roles.

Belton Middle School teachers Sarah Hagemann, Kilei Taylor, and Tyler Turner organized the event. The students who volunteered their time had their temperatures checked, practiced social distancing outside, wore masks, sanitized their work area frequently, washed their hands hourly, and also had a pizza lunch (always the best part, right?).

Thank you to all BMS CS&L students and teachers -- we love and appreciate you! #Proud2BPirates

Distance learning does not mean 100% online learning.

Our schools are providing paper packets for families who need or request this option. To get the packets ready for our Pirates, teachers prepare lessons and find supporting activities and then send the documents to school paraprofessionals. Our paras made arrangements to safely rotate into the schools and print the materials, sort them into packets, and prepare them for parent pick up.

It warmed our hearts to not only see the packets ready for pick up, but our schools were also able to offer school supplies, free books, and Harvesters backsnack packs.

We are grateful for the above and beyond we see happening in Belton. While our paraprofessionals and other staff may not be doing their "normal" jobs, everyone is contributing to the success of every student in some way! #Proud2BPirates

We just sent a reminder text to families and students -- we're pressing pause on distance learning for Monday and Tuesday so teachers can plan the next phase of lessons and prepare paper packets as needed.

Because learning looks different, preparing lessons is also very different. Teachers will be tuning into Zoom lessons to improve their technology and communication skills, writing lesson plans, and reflecting on what the next two weeks will include for our Pirates. Lessons will be tied to the curriculum standards, and many will also blend in some social-emotional learning activities; we realize this time can be confusing, frightening, stressful, and challenging for everyone.

So, we are using the phrase Just Press Pause, Pirates -- join us and use the two days to find a balance, prepare mentally and emotionally, and stay connected with each other.

We miss our students so much -- please give them hugs for us, parents and caregivers...then pause, breathe, and give yourself a hug, too.
You're all doing amazing things!
#Proud2BPirates

What a fun day to be a Pirate!

Belton Middle School 8th grader Esai Oquendo became the Cass County Spelling Bee Champion today -- which means he has qualified to compete at the Scripps National Spelling Bee in Washington, D.C.!

Six spellers participated in the Bee, which was hosted by the Raymore-Peculiar School District. Esai correctly spelled "celestial" to win. The runner-up was sixth-grader Lauren Cross from Pleasant Hill.

Congratulations to the other competitors representing Cass County districts: Quincy Carter, seventh grade, Harrisonville School District; Sofia Dardour, sixth grade, Midway School District; McKayla Hoover, sixth grade, Home School; and Audrey Mitchell, eighth grade, Ray-Pec South Middle School.

As the winner, Esai and a chaperone receive an all-expenses paid trip to Washington, D.C., to participate in the Scripps National Spelling Bee. The prize includes airfare, lodging, meals, and a spending allowance. He also received a trophy and a $50 Visa gift card from UMB Bank.

Belton Middle School teacher Alan Geels has been the assistant soccer coach at Belton High School for 27 years. After the boys' season ended, Head Coach Jared Smith told the other GKC Suburban Conference coaches the program wouldn't be what it is or where it is without Geels' dedication and commitment.
Smith told the coaches if they were considering voting for him, which often happens when the team is also the Conference champ, to instead cast their votes for Geels. The ballot decision was unanimous and Geels was named Conference Coach of the Year.
Geels was unable to attend the team banquet last week when they'd planned to surprise him with this award, so the team and parents were able to keep this on the down low...until after school today.
Congratulations, Coach Geels!

In the before and after school childcare program (SAC) at Cambridge Elementary School, students have been learning to sew. Site Director Whitney Hall shared, "They have been working on making pillows for about three weeks with Ms. Yesica (Gracia)." Their work started with tying knots with yarn then moved to do so with thread. Once they mastered the knots, it was on to tackling how to thread the needle. The students kept at it and eventually made their way to stitching and sewing on buttons.

Those basic skills gave them the foundation they needed to get down to business. The students designed a pillow and learned the value of having a pattern. SAC staff demonstrated the key parts of the sewing machine and each student was required to pass a safety quiz before using a sewing machine. We can't wait to see the finished products! #Proud2BPirates

Did you know Belton High School has a rich history with the A+ Program? We average around 225 seniors participating each year! Even if you are familiar with it, you may not know what "exactly" it can do for our Pirates...

In an effort to make college or vocational education available to every Missouri high school graduate, the Missouri General Assembly established the A+ Schools Program as part of the Outstanding Schools Act of 1993.

Graduates of designated A+ schools who successfully complete the requirements of the A+ Program may be eligible to receive reimbursement for the cost of tuition and general fees while attending a Missouri public community college or vocational/technical school.

Pretty amazing!
Here's one of our seniors in the program -- Stephanie Samer is an A+ student connected with staff and students at Mill Creek. She created this fabulous bulletin board for their vocal music room.
#Proud2BPirates

124 Things to know before school begins...#28

Our mission statement: Each time we go through a complete strategic planning process with staff, community members, and students (which is about every 5 years), the team revisits, reviews, revises, and revamps our mission.
It identifies what we aim to be and what we value.

It can be found on our website and framed on the walls in each building...and each school also has its own tailored mission statement!

"The mission of Belton School District #124, as a proud reflection of our community, is to inspire and empower all students to reach individual potential by providing learning experiences that challenge and engage within a safe, supportive environment designed to prepare students to thrive and excel."
#Proud2BPirates

Collaboration at its best -- and it's easy to see why these two staff members were Teacher of the Year and Support Staff of the Year finalists!

BOSCO paraprofessional Cheryl Kay reached out to Belton Middle School/Freshman Center band teacher Dylan Noble and asked for some instrument demonstrations for her elementary students because many of them had never heard these instruments in person. The students made the trip to the BMS Forum Theatre where a small group of Noble's band students performed a short clip of each instrument on stage, while also demonstrating other musical concepts like solos, duets, trios, and quartets. Then the entire jazz band played a few songs for them.

After all the performances were complete, each of the BOSCO students got to try out playing the tuba for fun! It was an amazing experience for students from both schools -- they were all able to learn, share, demonstrate, understand, and teach.

Both Kay and Noble said they are looking forward to more projects like this in the future! #Proud2BPirates

There will be no school in the Belton School District on Monday, May 27, 2019, in honor of Memorial Day.

"It's a day of thanks for the valor of others, a day to remember the splendor of America and those of her children who rest in this cemetery and others. It's a day to be with the family and remember." -- President Ronald Reagan at Arlington National Cemetery, 1986

Point of Information: On Memorial Day, the United States flag is to be hoisted with purpose in the morning, and lowered ceremoniously to half staff. At noon, the United States flag is to be raised to full staff and then lowered at sunset.

Since our district is closed on Monday, we will not be able to follow this important process. Therefore, we are following the protocol "if you are not able to fly the flag correctly, then it should not be flown." Our flags will be lowered on Friday afternoon and will be raised upon our return Tuesday.

Hillcrest now joins Kentucky Trail Elementary, Mill Creek Upper Elementary, and Grace Early Childhood as a National Schools of Character.

At the Cass County Job Olympics in April, several Belton students earned accolades for their efforts. One of the biggest celebrations of the day is always the Logan Gray Award presentation.
The award was created and named after a Pleasant Hill student who passed away in 2008. Gray loved his school and community and took pride in everything he did. The Job Olympics were one of his favorite activities each year. The award recognizes a student who demonstrates all of those things -- a love for school, community pride, and participation in the Job Olympics -- and more.

Five students from across the county are nominated for the award. They participate in an interview process with the Special Education Directors from each Northern Cass County District -- Pleasant Hill, Harrisonville, Cass Midway, Belton, and Raymore-Peculiar. Students do not have prior knowledge of what they'll be asked, but in the words of Belton teacher Nikki Mackay, Belton High School's nominee "nailed it."

Congratulations to junior Chase Lebow for being the 2019 recipient of the Logan Gray Award!
#Proud2BPirates

Belton High School's Service-Learning Leadership Class has been named TRACTION Team of the Year!

In addition to a very nice trophy, the group received a letter from Governor Parsons and a $500 grant to use for future activities and projects. TRACTION (formerly Team Spirit) is a youth traffic safety leadership training program designed to empower youth to take an active role in promoting safe driving habits. The program is sponsored by MoDOT and the Cape Girardeau Police Department.

This group of students has worked on driver safety throughout the year. Many of their activities were specifically designed for BHS students, but their biggest initiative was to get the city to pass a law to help save drivers' lives by wearing seat belts. They took the project from start to finish and City Council approved the ordinance to make Belton a Primary Seat Belt City! #Proud2BPIrates

Pictured with the mayor of Jefferson City: Caden Hand, Justice Howard, Ashleigh Waggoner, sponsor Mary Cummings, Emeline Bender, Savannah Eccles, and Emily Kerchner.
